channel.title: New to learning
channel.description:
Well its time I did something so I though why not eh? Lets learn a programming language.
There have been many topics on what one somebody should learn so I'm going to ask you lot (:P) so what one(s) have you learnt (if you have) why you chose it and why I should chose a certain one.
I would like to learn one that could possibly help me later in life.

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

Thanks for all the descriptions, and Niall. You saved my ass thanks.
When I finally choose something to learn I won’t be choosing it from the votes I will take into consideration the comments people have left on the different languages to learn, so far I’m thinking Java or C++, Delphi sounds nice though…

EDIT -: Taking into account with everything so far C++ and Java Are high on the list.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Compilers generate much more efficient asm code than humans do as they optimise it, you should write asm code yourself only as a last resort…

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @ruler ruler
item.description:
@ruler wrote:

Learn: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assembly_language

Most other languages build on it.

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

The only place I have use Perl is writing short shell scripts for Linux. It has great regular expressions ability.

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @JukuG JukuG
item.description:
@JukuG wrote:

Whilst we are talking about a variety of languages, could someone tell me what the purpose of Perl is? I mean, yeah you could do all sorts of stuff with it, but could someone point me in the direction of what it’s mainly used for.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @dreygoth dreygoth
item.description:

JAVA most usefull if u wont to make runescape and i dotn know about anything other then that so just what i say learn java man

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @zstars zstars
item.description:
@zstars wrote:

I have voted for Java, because, as you can see if you check my signature, I have recently written beginner tutorials for that language

I also voted for C++, simply because it is my favourite language.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:10, topic:180676”][quote author=Freddy1990 link=topic=242008.msg2049251#msg2049251 date=1202853210]
I myself as everyone knows use Delphi, which is powerful if used correctly and almost or as fast as c++ and it also supports inline ASM.
[/quote]

The compiler would be the thing that supports inline ASM, and gcc supports that in C and C++ I am pretty sure. :)[/quote]
Yes… And Borland Delphi is the only true compiler for the language… And I’m not saying it’s not supported in other languages…

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Interdit Interdit
item.description:
@Interdit wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:8, topic:180676”][quote author=Interdit link=topic=242008.msg2048057#msg2048057 date=1202794218]
Go write something huge, or a /real/ web service, and see how well a language like Python serves you.
[/quote]Seems to be serving Google pretty well.[/quote]Yah but Google have downs and mix 900 languages in a single service; I meant the entire system.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @JukuG JukuG
item.description:
@JukuG wrote:

I haven’t mastered it yet but I am currently learning C++ whenever I get time. For me it’s seems to be the only language where I don’t get lost altogether. Also, I am planning on tapping gaming so C++ was my choice seeing as it’s quite heavily used.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Freddy1990:

I myself as everyone knows use Delphi, which is powerful if used correctly and almost or as fast as c++ and it also supports inline ASM.

The compiler would be the thing that supports inline ASM, and gcc supports that in C and C++ I am pretty sure.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

Well, actually not each language would serve each purpose equally well, but I myself as everyone knows use Delphi, which is powerful if used correctly and almost or as fast as c++ and it also supports inline ASM. Of course it also has disadvantages as any language does, my second choice is c++ as it’s more basic than other language in the way that you are never bound to stuff you don’t need, which isn’t the case when using for example Borland’s VCL in delphi.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Interdit:

Go write something huge, or a /real/ web service, and see how well a language like Python serves you.

Seems to be serving Google pretty well.

PS. Yes I am well aware Google also use Java quite heavily.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

I changed “Pearl” to “Perl”, and removed C+, I think you mean C#, in that case, just learn Java.

I also voted Java, it will give you a pretty good introduction to OOP and programming in general, it’s easy and you can find some fantastic help sites.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Interdit:

Different languages serve different uses, it depends what you are planning on making. Anyway, once you understand how programming really works, languages will not be a barrier to you, at heart they all operate in the same way.

Exactly. At least for most languages, there are always the funky ones like logic programming with something like prolog that is VERY different, but procedural languages all operate the same.

Java is an excellent place to start, and you can write large applications with it as well, so that is what I would recommend for you.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

C+ and pearl are good. I voted Other because I code batch.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @Interdit Interdit
item.description:
@Interdit wrote:

xxlegitxx:

Java takes plenty of space to write, and it’s slow.

Java == slow.

Also, you are only looking at these languages from your perspective (writing tiny little client applications that constitute 0 code reuse), hence you have a misperception of “bloated” code.

Java isn’t designed for that (in my opinion). Go write something huge, or a /real/ web service, and see how well a language like Python serves you.

Different languages serve different uses, it depends what you are planning on making. Anyway, once you understand how programming really works, languages will not be a barrier to you, at heart they all operate in the same way.

Also, “Pearl” does not exist, it’s Perl. And neither does C+.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Java takes plenty of space to write, and it’s slow.

Python is slow, but at least it’s concise.

Read full topic

item.title: New to learning
item.dc:creator: @eVokki1 Cowie`
item.description:
@eVokki1 wrote:

I picked Python and Java.

Java reasons:

Alot of people like Java, there is a hell of a lot of a support for it, the community surrounding the language is very helpful.
On this forum there are quite a few able Java programmers, you might get some help from them.

Python:

Ever since Evil_ convinced me to learn Python I’ve loved it, you can use something called Pava which will enable you to use Java inside Python, to call forward classes etc.
The language is simple, easy to understand and multi-platform.
irc.freenode.net #python - The people on that channel are so fucking helpful.

cocks.

Read full topic
